ygData.subject: New Paper on Generating Musical Harmony with NEAT
ygData.msgSnippet: Amy Hoover, Paul Szerlip, and I are pleased to announce our new paper to appear at GECCO, Interactively Evolving Harmonies through Functional Scaffolding.

Subject: New Paper on Generating Musical Harmony with NEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=5GtuOKvFwlobU0CniCsinDpSp-77u9aLCAeBRKKmjND9YQbEXk8B

Amy Hoover, Paul Szerlip, and I are pleased to announce our new paper to ap=
pear at GECCO, "Interactively Evolving Harmonies through Functional Scaffol=
ding."  You can download it here:

http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/hoover_ge=
cco11.pdf

Abstract: http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2011/hoover.gecco=
11.html

There is also a page of musical samples from the paper that you ca=
n listen to here:

http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/fsmc/gecco2011/

Some of you may=
 remember NEAT Drummer, which evolved drum tracks to accompany existing pie=
ces.  Amy and I (and now Paul too) have intended for a long time to extend =
the theory behind NEAT Drummer to full-blown harmonization.  The basic idea=
 is that different parts of a composition can be expressed as *functions* o=
f each other.  Therefore, if you have some parts already written, then you =
can apply an evolved function (encoded as a CPPN evolved by NEAT) to those =
parts and it will automatically output an accompaniment.  Because the accom=
paniment is a function of the preexisting parts (which we call the "scaffol=
d"), it naturally follows their contours.  In other words, you can get surp=
risingly good accompaniments in very few generations of interactive evoluti=
on.  The overall approach is called Functional Scaffolding for Musical Comp=
osition (FSMC), which can evolve complete original harmonies (i.e. not just=
 drums) or even novel melodies to accompany existing harmonies.

You can li=
sten to some samples at the link above and we will be sharing more in the f=
uture.  We added a couple "bonus tracks" to the page (of accompaniment gene=
rated for Scarborough Fair from only generation 3) that are not from the pa=
per, but we think you'll find them surprisingly good in any case.  We're ha=
ving a lot of fun applying FSMC to lots of different kinds of music and sur=
prising ourselves with the creative variations it comes up.  We hope to rel=
ease the actual application in the coming months for others to play with as=
 well.

ken
